### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>Input: Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda. Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Output: Mara has 150 - 40 = <<150-40=110>>110 cards.<n>Janet has 110/2 = <<110/2=55>>55 cards since Mara has twice as many as Janet.<n>Brenda has 55 - 9 = <<55-9=46>>46 cards since Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda.<n>Therefore, they all have 110 + 55 + 46 = <<110+55+46=211>>211 cards.<n>So the final answer is 211<n><n>Input:Sammy wanted to go to where the people were.  Where might he go? Choices:  A: race track B: populated areas C: the desert D: apartment E: roadblock<n>Output:		<n>    - E: <<roadrblock.txt>><n>    A: where the people were<<race.txt>><n>    D: desert<<desert.txt>><n>    B is populated areas<<pop.txt>><n>    C the desert<<desert.text>><n>Input:  The best way to do math with a calculator? Choices:  Use the keypad  A: press 5 or B: press 0 or C: press 9 D: press 9 and then 0  or press 6<n>Output:<n>A: press 5<<press.txt>><n>D: press 9 and press 0<<press.txt>>or press 6<<press6.txt>><n>B: press 0<<press0.txt>><n>C: the calculator<<calculator.txt>><n><n>Input:  A person bought 133 pounds of potatoes. How much more potatos did they buy than pineapples? Choices: A: 1 B: 13 C: 36 D: none<n>Output:  B: 13<<b.txt>><n><n>### Input:  There are 254 students at the school. How many fewer are there than 200? Choices: A. 200 B. 300 C. 500 D. 0<n>Output:  A: 200<<a.txt>><n>A person bought <<potato.txt>> pounds of potatoes. He also bought <<pine.txt>> pounds of pineapples. He actually bought <<potato+pineapples.txt>> pounds of food.<n><n>A: 300<<tie.txt>> B: 100 C: 340 D: 30<n><n>### Input :  Marcy needed <<a little.txt>> gallons of gas for the car.  How many more gallons is there than a quart?  Choices: A: <<a little+quart.txt>> B: <<a little-a quart.txt>> C: none<n>Output: B: <<a little - a quart.txt>><n>
### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>Input: Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda. Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Output: Mara has 150 - 40 = <<150-40=110>>110 cards.<n>Janet has 110/2 = <<110/2=55>>55 cards since Mara has twice as many as Janet.<n>Brenda has 55 - 9 = <<55-9=46>>46 cards since Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda.<n>Therefore, they all have 110 + 55 + 46 = <<110+55+46=211>>211 cards.<n>So the final answer is 211<n><n>Input:What home entertainment equipment requires cable? Output 24 is the answer.<n>

Choices: A: vegetable B: meat C: fried food D: raw vegetables E: fruit<n>Output:Fried food is unhealthy because of its oil (or butter) content when fried. Meat is also full of preservatives and hormones that are not healthy for the humans. Vegetables and fruit are healthy and raw vegetables are more healthier since the nutrients are unchanged.<n><n>Input: What are the characteristics of an object with mass? Choices: A) Weightless B) Massless C) Made of ice D) Made of air E) Unbreakable<n>Output: Mass is the measure of the inertia of a given object, whereas weight is the measure of force needed to move it. Both of these properties are measured in “Newtons”. We can distinguish them by checking what they have in common: both are measured with a scale that measures weight. Objects are heavy if they have more mass and their gravitational pull will also be stronger. It will also be harder to move these objects (this is the definition of inertia!). They are not weightless.<n><n>Input: Who is the fastest car in the world? Choices: A. McLaren B. Ferrari C. Lamborghini D. Honda E. ### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>Input: Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda. Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Output: Mara has 150 - 40 = <<150-40=110>>110 cards.<n>Janet has 110/2 = <<110/2=55>>55 cards since Mara has twice as many as Janet.<n>Brenda has 55 - 9 = <<55-9=46>>46 cards since Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda.<n>Therefore, they all have 110 + 55 + 46 = <<110+55+46=211>>211 cards.<n>So the final answer is 211<n><n>Input:Where would you find a seafood restaurant in the east coast of North America? Choices:  A: maine B: boston C: beach town D: coastal cities E: ocean<n>Output:		Maine has a lot of sea food restaurants, especially lobster.<n><n>### Instruction: Write each rule and apply it to the given input.<n>Input: The rule is “A is the mother of B if and only if Bis the daughter of A.”<n>Output:A: Mom B: daughter/wife<n><n>### Instructions: Write each rule and convert its symbolic form to a truth table. Answer the question if necessary<n>Input:The rule: If A and B are sets of real numbers with cardinality k and k = 2 then <math>{\sqrt {2\sqrt { A } - A + \sqrt {A}^{2}} }</math> is an integer.<n><n>Output:The rule is true. We want to prove two sets have the same size. If A and B are non empty and A B = A + B then |A + B| = | A|+|B| for the case of A B = 0 we have by definition of disjunction that A B or not.<n><n>We need a base case and an inductive case:<n><n>Base case: Suppose |A|=|B|=1 then that means A={0},B={0} so <math>{\sqrt 0 - 0 + 0 }</math> is not an integer<n>Inductive case: Suppose for k < n it is true that if there are two sets A and B with <math>|A|=k</math> and <math>|B|=k</math>. For k < n+1  we want to show that if there are two non empty A and B with < math>|A| =  k +1 and <math>| B| = k < n+1</math>.<n>Proof:<n>Therefor we get that: <math>0< \sqrt 0 - 1 + 0 = 0</math>.<n>Now for the inductive case we have the following inequality: <math><math>\sqrt 0 - 2 + 1 </ math>= <math>0.</math><n>We want to show that <math>0 < \sqrt 0 -3 + 2</math>, for that we have:< math> <math>\sqrt 0-1 + 3 < \sqrt 0-1+1+3</math> < math> = 2</

How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Output: Mara has 150 - 40 = <<150-40=110>>110 cards.<n>Janet has 110/2 = <<110/2=55>>55 cards since Mara has twice as many as Janet.<n>Brenda has 55 - 9 = <<55-9=46>>46 cards since Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda.<n>Therefore, they all have 110 + 55 + 46 = <<110+55+46=211>>211 cards.<n>So the final answer is 211<n><n>Input:A beaver can destroy a machines functionality if they build their dam in this? Choices:  a: 35 b: 33 c: 15 d: 7 e: 4<n>Output: The answer to the equation is B (33 candles). Since Anna is 15 you add 15, so in all she has 15 candles. If you add the first option's 5 and the last option's 5 you get 10. You just added 15 and 10 together. So 25 must mean 15 plus 10, but this can't be true since 15 is the whole answer. So 15 must mean Anna's birthday, because when you add the two birthdays together, they come out to Anna's original number. So in total you got 33 candles.<n><n>Input: If 8 men can mow a lawn in 20 minutes, how long will it take 4 men and a boy to do it? How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Output: Mara has 150 - 40 = <<150-40=110>>110 cards.<n>Janet has 110/2 = <<110/2=55>>55 cards since Mara has twice as many as Janet.<n>Brenda has 55 - 9 = <<55-9=46>>46 cards since Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda.<n>Therefore, they all have 110 + 55 + 46 = <<110+55+46=211>>211 cards.<n>So the final answer is 211<n><n>Input:What could listening to music cause you to be? Choices:  A: happy B: smile C: calm D: entertainment E: relaxation<n>Output:		A is correct because a smile, a calm and relaxation are all caused due to music listening.<n><n>Test: 1. Write the number of letters in the following words: a) sassy b) deceptive c) ruse d) dandy e) sassy<n>Output: 1. sassy, 2. deceptive, 3. ruse, 4. dandy, 5. sassy<n>2. You were born in the month of April in what year? April is the fourth month of the year.<n>Output: 1972<n>3. Bring me some bread and __________<n>Output: 1) butter 2) jam 3) cheese 4) mustard<n>4. In 1989, what is the answer to 91 × 27?<n>Output: 2483<n>5. Add 50 and 150.<n>Output: 200
### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>Input: Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda. Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Output: Mara has 150 - 40 = <<150-40=110>>110 cards.<n>Janet has 110/2 = <<110/2=55>>55 cards since Mara has twice as many as Janet.<n>Brenda has 55 - 9 = <<55-9=46>>46 cards since Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda.<n>Therefore, they all have 110 + 55 + 46 = <<110+55+46=211>>211 cards.<n>So the final answer is 211<n><n>Input:"There are 10 apples on an apple tree.  Three fall off.  Now there are X apples."  What is this an example of? Choices:  A: park B: coloring book C: garden center D: math problem E: gravity<n>Output:		Gravity. Because the falling apples are an example of it.<n><n><n><n>---<n>- [Instruction Sheet and Practice Questions](https://forms.gle/k1Rbw82CYGgwqCZV6)<n>

Because of his mistake, he spent 8 years somewhere. Where was he? Choices:  A: prison B: bridge C: locked up D: homeless shelter E: neighbor's house<n>Output:		Ben has a neighbor's house because the sentence says he was in an accident, so he was home injured and probably incapacitated. This answer is E.<n>2. Ben was never a prisoner. This answer is C.<n><n>Input:A boy lost his ball. He asked his friend where he lost it. ### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>Input: Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda. Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Output: Mara has 150 - 40 = <<150-40=110>>110 cards.<n>Janet has 110/2 = <<110/2=55>>55 cards since Mara has twice as many as Janet.<n>Brenda has 55 - 9 = <<55-9=46>>46 cards since Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda.<n>Therefore, they all have 110 + 55 + 46 = <<110+55+46=211>>211 cards.<n>So the final answer is 211<n><n>Input:John came to see Sam and Sam kicked him out.  Sam didn't like company.  He prefered what? Choices:  A: you B: abbreviation C: solitude D: loneliness E: alone<n>Output:		Sam was talking about solitude. The sentence is "Sam didn't like company/company is not preferred..."<n><n><n>### Instruction:Answer the questions below.<n><n>```<n>>>>from random import uniform, choice <n><n>>>>print(uniform(-1, 1))<n>0.809668141554404<n><n>>>>print((choice<uniform(-1, 6)))<n>0.36607038430043483<n>```<n><n>What is the probability that one or more of these two numbers will occur?<n><n>Answer: In this case, all we need to do is add the probabilities as follows:<n><n>P(0.809<uniform(-1,1))+P(0.366>=uniform(-1,1)), which reduces as follows:<n>P(0.355<uniform(-1,2))+P(0<uniform(-1,4)), which further reduces as follows:<n>1/2*[1-(0-0.355)]+[0-1], which results in 1/2 as the probability.<n><n><n>Explanation:<n>The probability of the outcomes in question can be represented as fractions or percentage.<n>The fractional representation for it is given as P(0.80<uniform(-1.5,1)), where, 0.809 (0.81 according to python) as the value of uniform(0,1), which forms the left hand side of the inequality and (1-0.809)/2  or 0.190 as the value of the right hand side.  <n>Now, the probability of this occurring is 0.81/0.190 or 1/2.<n>Similarly, the probability of the outcomes can also be computed. The same can be extended to all the outcomes in the question.<n>This forms the probability of occurrence of at least one outcome given in the question.<n>
### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>Input: Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda. Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Output: Mara has 150 - 40 = <<150-40=110>>110 cards.<n>Janet has 110/2 = <<110/2=55>>55 cards since Mara has twice as many as Janet.<n>Brenda has 55 - 9 = <<55-9=46>>46 cards since Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda.<n>Therefore, they all have 110 + 55 + 46 = <<110+55+46=211>>211 cards.<n>So the final answer is 211<n><n>Input:What's it called when you have seen something through an eyepiece? Choices:  A: sights B: optical illusion C: optical telescope D: light microscope E: binocular<n>Output:		sights<n><n><n>## What is the value of the number below?<n><n>Input: 0x3000000<n><n>Output: 43241034566034107210954265156619541<n><n>## #47892 - 45762<n><n>Output: 211275704867074251<n><n>## Why does C get a 2 on the first input, since C would correspond to the second input by value?<n><n>## How to calculate the smallest prime number that fits in 32 bits?<n><n>### Input: 1001010001001111000110100100001<n><n>Output: 84142736<n><n>### Input:-413187920<n><n>Output: +1<n><n>## Why are we using 'x % 16' as the mod instead of 'x % 10' or 40?<n><n>## The given problem asks us to return the smallest prime number that is one greater than the input number. However, it appears that the smallest prime number that also fits in the input number may be not the same.<n><n>## 0x30<n><n>Output: <<0000030>><n><n>## 0<n><n>Output:<n><n>## 00000E6A<n><n>Output: <<118176690492211453079<<<<<n><n>## The given question is asking how to find the sum of all prime numbers till 100 million. When we run the given code to sum those numbers it gives an output of 9107826879774971. This is a mistake, while there is a discrepancy in the base given. The base is 16 not 10. So we can use 0x7fffff to sum the numbers as given in the problem.<n>

How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Output: Mara has 150 - 40 = <<150-40=110>>110 cards.<n>Janet has 110/2 = <<110/2=55>>55 cards since Mara has twice as many as Janet.<n>Brenda has 55 - 9 = <<55-9=46>>46 cards since Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda.<n>Therefore, they all have 110 + 55 + 46 = <<110+55+46=211>>211 cards.<n>So the final answer is 211<n><n>Input:What enables most people to transport themselves? Choices:  A: helicopter B: own cars C: speak words D: believe in god E: dance together<n>Output:		Moving is for people who believe in God since God always helps people moving, people who dance together(they can't go far distances), people who own cars, people who says words(they can't walk that far), and people who moves on their helicopter.<n>Answer:E

### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>Input: Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda. Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Output: Mara has 150 - 40 = <<150-40=110>>110 cards.<n>Janet has 110/2 = <<110/2=55>>55 cards since Mara has twice as many as Janet.<n>Brenda has 55 - 9 = <<55-9=46>>46 cards since Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda.<n>Therefore, they all have 110 + 55 + 46 = <<110+55+46=211>>211 cards.<n>So the final answer is 211<n><n>Input:John enjoyed his time visiting the museum.  He wanted to spend more time there, so that he could study the exhibits more.   He was a very academic person and loved doing what? Choices:  A: tired feet B: gaining knowledge C: back pain D: being bored E: pondering<n>Output:		All of the choices have been eliminated but choices B, D, and E which are:  <<"He was a very academic person"(verb) "and loved doing what?">>.<n>The remaining choices in the original sentence are "Choices:"A: tired feet B: "gaining"(preposition) "knowledge"(noun) C: "<back>(determiner) <pain>(noun)"(noun) D: "being"(adverb)"bored"(adjective) E: "pondering"  (verb) F: None of the above<n><n>Input: <<"I hope that my boyfriend comes home early today,">><n><n>So the sentence structure is:   <n>I hope that [ boyfriend ] comes home early today<n>The verb in this sentence is: <<I hope that [ verb ] comes home>><n>The verb is hope (subject ) and the verb came home is the predicate(direct object ) and is completed by [ boyfriend ] <n><n><n>Input: There is no one else in the house but a little baby.<n><n>Structure:   There is no one else (noun)  but a little (noun)  baby. The smoke will be composed of carbon particles since carbon dioxide will escape from the wood. Carbon particles will coat the surface of the polished wood and act as a mirror to reflect what is happening on the other side, which would be a window or a doorframe etc.<n>Input: How many different integers are there in the range of 1<n<10 such that n doesn’t end in 9?<n>Output:3<n>Since n doesn’t end with 9, so<n>0<n<10:<n>n= 1<<1:<n>1\- 1 = 0<n>n= 2<<1:<n>2\- 10 = 9<n>n= 3<<1:<n>3\- 9 = 4<n>n= 4<<<1:<n>4>>=0<n>n= 5<<1:<n>5>>=9<n>n= 6<<1:<n>6>6=0<n>n=…<n>n= 9<<1:<n>9>9=0<n>n= \-9<<1:<n>\-9\>=0<n>n= \ 0<<1:<n>=6\- 9\+ 9\<n>n= \-6<<1:<n>\<n>n=9 \- 6 = \- 3<n>n=5\- 3\ = \- 2<n>n= \- 2<<1: 111\- 2\ =\ \ 99\<n>n= 3\- 1 = \- 0<n><n>Input: What is the 2nd derivative of a function of the form: y = x^a. ### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>Input: Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda. Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Output: Mara has 150 - 40 = <<150-40=110>>110 cards.<n>Janet has 110/2 = <<110/2=55>>55 cards since Mara has twice as many as Janet.<n>Brenda has 55 - 9 = <<55-9=46>>46 cards since Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda.<n>Therefore, they all have 110 + 55 + 46 = <<110+55+46=211>>211 cards.<n>So the final answer is 211<n><n>Input:Where is microphone boom likely to be used to record an album? ### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>Input: Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda. Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Output: Mara has 150 - 40 = <<150-40=110>>110 cards.<n>Janet has 110/2 = <<110/2=55>>55 cards since Mara has twice as many as Janet.<n>Brenda has 55 - 9 = <<55-9=46>>46 cards since Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda.<n>Therefore, they all have 110 + 55 + 46 = <<110+55+46=211>>211 cards.<n>So the final answer is 211<n><n>Input:The man was cleaning clothes for his date, what was he looking to achieve? Choices:  A: ruined B: clean clothes C: sadness D: attractive appearance E: look better<n>Output:		the man was looking to achieve attractive appearance by looking better.<n><n>---<n>### Instruction:Design a program that accepts input from a file.<n><n>1.Open a file called user.txt and write the names and age of your family members whose ages are 31, 28, 24, 17.<n>2.Also write a message next to each member that congratulates them on completing 15 years of age, respectively the first family member at 15 years, the second at 20 years, and so forth.<n>Output:Congratulations. Your whole family has just completed 15 years<n>3.The computer should add the ages of each and create a printout with the sum of the 4 ages.<n>Output:The sum of 31, 31, 45,49 is 146 for the whole family members <n><n>---<n>```python<n>f1 = open('user.txt', 'r')                          #open the file <n>names=[]                                               #empty Lists<n>ages = []                                                  <n>f1.readline()                                                   #to get the first line and store in variable<n>f1.readlines()                                                    # to take all the line in the file<n>for line in f1:<n>	x = line.split()<n>	for  x in x:<n>		x = input(x)<n>	names.append(x.strip()) <n>	ages.append(int(x))    <n>print(names)<n>```<n>---<n>## Instruction:Input user's first name, last name, and age.<n><n>Input:John Doe 26<n>Output:John is 26<n><n>---<n><n>```python<n>firstname = input('Enter your First name: ')  <n>lastname = input('Enter you Last name: ')<n>#print('Your First Name is ', firstname)<n>#print('Your Last Name is ', lastname)<n>age = int(input('Enter your age: '))    <n>print('Your name is ', firstname, lastname,  'and your age is ', age)<n>#print ('Your name is',firstname)<n>```  <n>---<n>## Instructions:Input 5 numbers.<n><n>Then calculate the sum of
### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>Input: Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda. Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Output: Mara has 150 - 40 = <<150-40=110>>110 cards.<n>Janet has 110/2 = <<110/2=55>>55 cards since Mara has twice as many as Janet.<n>Brenda has 55 - 9 = <<55-9=46>>46 cards since Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda.<n>Therefore, they all have 110 + 55 + 46 = <<110+55+46=211>>211 cards.<n>So the final answer is 211<n><n>Input:What would an adult man do to get ready for work? Choices:  A: dress herself B: shower C: dress himself D: drink beer E: drive train<n>Output:		Choice B<<B:::Choi 2, Choice C<<C:-3, Choice D<<D:-0.33, Choice E<<E:0>>0>>0 which corresponds to the choice "shower".<n><n>Input: The average weight for a horse is 1364. Choices B is the choice with the fewest number of people, Choice D is the choice with the largest number of people, Choices A and E are choices with the largest number of horses.<n>Output: Choice E<<E:-0.65>>-0.65 which corresponds to the choice Average Weight.<n><n>Input: Average Weight is the same as Choice E<n>Output: Average Weight<n><n>Input: Choice B<<2, Choice D<<3, Choice C<<4>>4>>4<n>Output: Choice C<<C:4>>4.<n>The smallest number among these 3 choices is choice B<<2, Choices A and B both contain the same number, hence Choice B<<2 is the smallest.<n><n>Input: An adult man dresses himself.<n>Output: An adult man.<n>
### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>Input: Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda. Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Output: Mara has 150 - 40 = <<150-40=110>>110 cards.<n>Janet has 110/2 = <<110/2=55>>55 cards since Mara has twice as many as Janet.<n>Brenda has 55 - 9 = <<55-9=46>>46 cards since Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda.<n>Therefore, they all have 110 + 55 + 46 = <<110+55+46=211>>211 cards.<n>So the final answer is 211<n><n>Input:Simon bought a cow because he wanted to put it to work.   He didn't want any meat for it.  Where might Simon be taking the cow? Choices:  A: countryside B: city C: dairy farm D: butcher shop E: canada<n>Output:		Simon sold his cow at the butcher shop.<n>He is taking the cow to the butcher shop.  The choices: butcher shop, countryside, dairy farm and city, don't make any sense.<n>Simon buys the cow with the intention of selling it for it's meat(not milk), so he's taking it to the butcher shop, not the dairy farm. He doesn't want any meat from it. I'm assuming that this is a riddle, not a question.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the question correctly.
### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>Input: Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda. Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Output: Mara has 150 - 40 = <<150-40=110>>110 cards.<n>Janet has 110/2 = <<110/2=55>>55 cards since Mara has twice as many as Janet.<n>Brenda has 55 - 9 = <<55-9=46>>46 cards since Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda.<n>Therefore, they all have 110 + 55 + 46 = <<110+55+46=211>>211 cards.<n>So the final answer is 211<n><n>Input:If I want to maximize my number of potential customers, where should I build a new department store? ### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>Input: Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda. Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Output: Mara has 150 - 40 = <<150-40=110>>110 cards.<n>Janet has 110/2 = <<110/2=55>>55 cards since Mara has twice as many as Janet.<n>Brenda has 55 - 9 = <<55-9=46>>46 cards since Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda.<n>Therefore, they all have 110 + 55 + 46 = <<110+55+46=211>>211 cards.<n>So the final answer is 211<n><n>Input:Where can someone keep a digital file? Choices:  A: suitcase B: filing cabinet C: computer D: desk drawer E: cloud<n>Output:		A<n>Explanation: A digital file is any document, such as a word processor file or PDF, that is stored in digital format. It is usually created or edited through software to produce files that can be easily stored, shared, and edited by others.Digital files are typically stored in computers, smartphones, tablets, or other devices, and can also be stored in the cloud or on a network server. Files can also be stored on removable storage media, such as USB flash drives or external hard drives.Some common types of digital files include documents, images, music, video, and archives. Digital files can be accessed through various devices and platforms, including computers, smartphones and tablets, digital cameras, and smart home devices.The storage and sharing of digital files can be done securely through encryption and passwords, and can also be organized and accessed using file management software.<n><n>### Code:Use the following steps to create a function that takes a number and an array of numbers as parameters, and returns a new array with the numbers from the<n>given array that are not in the provided parameter.<n>If the given parameter is not in the array, the new array should not contain it.<n>If the parameter is contained in the array, the function should return the array as-is.<n>```javascript<n>Input: ['f', 'h', 'j', 'k', 'n']<n>Output:  ['f', 'h']<n>Explanation: n is not in the array but f and h are, so the result is ['f', 'h'].<n><n>Input: ['l', 'b', 'n', 'p']<n>Output:  []<n>Explanation: l is not in the array. If b, n, or p are entered as the parameter, they will also not be in the array, so it's empty.<n><n>```<n>*<n>> function notInList(arr, val)<n> <n><n>   arr.some((elt) => elt!== val)<n> ```<n>

### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>Input: Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda. Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Output: Mara has 150 - 40 = <<150-40=110>>110 cards.<n>Janet has 110/2 = <<110/2=55>>55 cards since Mara has twice as many as Janet.<n>Brenda has 55 - 9 = <<55-9=46>>46 cards since Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda.<n>Therefore, they all have 110 + 55 + 46 = <<110+55+46=211>>211 cards.<n>So the final answer is 211<n><n>Input:Where will a bullet projectile be found during a war? Choices:  A: battle field B: museum C: weapon D: canon E: tornado<n>Output:		War will not occur. Only if there is a gun shooting and some shell casing fall on battlefield will there be a bullet projectile.<n><n><n>### Task 1: Inventory<n><n>```python<n>def inventory(x, y):<n>    output=[]<n>    if  x>y:<n>        output.append(int(x/y))<n>        left_over=x%y<n>        if left_over == 0:<n>            output.append(y)<n>        else: output.append(str(left_over)+" "+str(y))<n>    else:<n>        output.reverse()<n>        <n>    print(output)<n>```<n>### Task 2: Checking for even number<n>```python<n>def check_for_even(n):<n>    output=[1,2,4,8,16]<n>    even_index=[]<n>    for i in range(len(output)):<n>        even_index.append(output[i])<n>    for x in even_index:<n>        sum_even=0<n>        for y in even_index: <n>            sum_even += y<n>        if sum_even%2==0:<n>            print(x*even_index[sum_even//2]==n)<n>```<n>##  Multiple Tasks <n>###  Task 1: Check the given number is perfect square or not<n>```python<n>def is_perfect_square(x):<n>    x2 = int(x*x)<n>    if x2//x == int(x2//x):<n>        return True<n>    else:<n>    	return False<n>```

So it means not good enough.<n>

### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>Input: Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda. Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Output: Mara has 150 - 40 = <<150-40=110>>110 cards.<n>Janet has 110/2 = <<110/2=55>>55 cards since Mara has twice as many as Janet.<n>Brenda has 55 - 9 = <<55-9=46>>46 cards since Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda.<n>Therefore, they all have 110 + 55 + 46 = <<110+55+46=211>>211 cards.<n>So the final answer is 211<n><n>Input:Where would you put a light? Choices: A: <n>0.0am <n>B: <n>0.3am<n>C: <n>7.0am <n>D: <n>7.3am<n>Output: C: 7.0am<n><n>#Python<n><n>Instructions: Given a positive integer N, use a maximum of N iterations to solve the following equation: x^2 - x = x<n><n>#Python<n>#Defining the variable<n>x = int(raw_input("Please input: "))<n>#Defining the equation<n>f = x**2 - x<n><n>#Start the loop<n>k = 0<n><n>#While the loop<n>#While the condition k < N<n>#If the loop is true<n>if f == x:<n>    print "The soln is : "+str(x)<n>#Print out the number of iteration<n>print "The number of iteration is : "+str(k)<n>k = k + 1<n>#The while ends<n>#If the loop isn't true<n>else:<n>    f = f + x<n>print "The equasion after the current iteration is :"+str(f)<n>k = k <n>    #The while ends<n>#Ends the loop<n>while k >= 0 and k <= N<n>    k = k - 1<n>    f = f<n><n>#The program ends<n>print "The program ends"<n>

### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>Input: Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda. Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Output: Mara has 150 - 40 = <<150-40=110>>110 cards.<n>Janet has 110/2 = <<110/2=55>>55 cards since Mara has twice as many as Janet.<n>Brenda has 55 - 9 = <<55-9=46>>46 cards since Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda.<n>Therefore, they all have 110 + 55 + 46 = <<110+55+46=211>>211 cards.<n>So the final answer is 211<n><n>Input:What is made out of only one piece? Example of 'jigsaw puzzel pucxle' is made up from two pieces.<n><n>Input: Find the solution for this equation:  5x - 2 - 3x + 12 + 2x + 5/2 = 15. Choices:  A) x = 4 B) x = 0 C) x = 9<n>Output: Answer is Choice D which is x=5/4<n>The correct answer is choice d.<n><n>#1. For input 2,5,9,12 there are 10 different combinations to select from,<n>#2. for input 2,5 there are 6 12 18 21 24,<n>#3. for input 9,9 we can see that there is the only 6 possible combo.<n>#4. answer Choice D because its possible and logical because there's only two options left at that point.<n>#5. for input 3,3 we have 4 possible combo left. Choosen 3 because its the least possible choice and its unique for that number.<n>#6. answer Choice B or C because the equation was solved and the value is 15, not 12.<n><n>#7. the answer Choice B is right because there are two inputs and when one of them is subtracted and added the other, then the numbers should be equal to each other.<n><n>#8. the answer Choice E is Right because one input is less than the other and that should equal zero.<n><n>#9. the answer Choice A is right because the equation says that there's only a 0.5, which is a half so that can only mean one digit and should equal zero.<n> #10. the answer Choice C is right because a multiple of four would make the number that much.<n> #11. the answer choice is C because there is two inputs, if one is doubled and added to the other the answer would be 13, which only would have one value at that time, so the 2 and 3 can be cancelled out.<n><n>#12. the answer E since it says 2,5,6

### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>Input: Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda. Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Output: Mara has 150 - 40 = <<150-40=110>>110 cards.<n>Janet has 110/2 = <<110/2=55>>55 cards since Mara has twice as many as Janet.<n>Brenda has 55 - 9 = <<55-9=46>>46 cards since Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda.<n>Therefore, they all have 110 + 55 + 46 = <<110+55+46=211>>211 cards.<n>So the final answer is 211<n><n>Input:How might people perceive someone they are scared of? Choices:  A: human B: happy C: dangerous D: strange E: weird<n>Output:		D<n>How people perceive someone they’re scared of:<n>A. = human<n><n>B. = happy<n><n>C. = dangerous<n><n>D. = strange<n><n>E. =Weird<n><n>Choices D & E represent the same answer, so the correct answer is D.<n><n>### Instruction:Write the Python code that implements the rules for the next multiple choice question.<n>Input: You are supposed to create a program such that it asks for the name of the player (first), followed by the color of the ball (second), and then the color of the ground (third).<n>The program will print a message that says:<n><n>'<color of ball><color of the ground> is a good colour combination for the ball and <name of the player>'.<n><n>So, you should create the program that asks for 3 inputs.<n><n>Output: After the third input, the program will ask for your name.<n><n>Input:<n>Both players are Red.<n><n>Print<n><n>'<Player names>' is a good team.'<n><n>Output:<n><n>Input:<n>First player is red and second one is yellow.<n><n>Print<n>'<Player names> is the better colour combo for winning.'<n><n>In the event that the player names are the same, then print this string.'<Player names> is also a good name for the same colour.'<n>Input:<n>First one is Blue, second one is purple, the third is Red.<n><n>Print either<n>'<player names> would make a good winning combination'<n>or<n>'<player names>' is a good colour combo for winning.<n><n>Output:<n>Input:<n>The two teams are purple and yellow.<n><n>Print '<Player names> are not a good combination for winning.'<n><n>Output:`You may change the order of the names of the players at the beginning`.<n>Input:<n>For the Red team you have 3 players, with Green as ground colour, the Blue team has 2 players with Brown as ground colour.<n><n>Print 'Red has 2 + 3 = 5 players while the Blue has 2 =<5 and they have a good chance of winning.'.<n>
### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>Input: Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda. Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Output: Mara has 150 - 40 = <<150-40=110>>110 cards.<n>Janet has 110/2 = <<110/2=55>>55 cards since Mara has twice as many as Janet.<n>Brenda has 55 - 9 = <<55-9=46>>46 cards since Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda.<n>Therefore, they all have 110 + 55 + 46 = <<110+55+46=211>>211 cards.<n>So the final answer is 211<n><n>Input:Where do farmers keep toothpicks? Choices:  A: mouth B: grocery store C: constructing models D: shed E: box<n>Output:		D<<D:Shed>><n><n>### My Solution<n>```python<n>ans=211<n>```<n>Input: Janet  has 9 cards more  than Brenda.  Mara  has twice as many cards  as Janet. How  many  cards  do they  have   all  if  Mara  has    40  cards less than 170?  Output: Mara  has  150 - 20 =  << 150-20 =130 >> 130 cards.  Janet  has  42/2 =  <<  42/2=21>>  21  cards since Mara  has  twice  as many  as  Janet.  Brenda  has 21-9 =  << 21-9=12>>  12 cards  since  Janet  has 10 cards more  than  Brenda.  Therefore,  they   all  have  150 + 42 + 12 =  << 1  150+42+12 =1 105>>  132  cards.  So the  final  answer  is 162<n>Input:Where do  farmers keep tooth picks? Choices: A:  Mouth B: Grocery store C: Building models D: Shed  E: Box  Output: D<<D : Shed>><n>```python<n>ans = 162<n><n># I think Janet has (9+42)/2 = 55 cards, Brenda has 42-9=33 cards,<n># Mara has 210/2 = 105, then they have 105+55+33 = (1 + 55+33) = 162 cards<n><n>```<n><n>### My explanation<n>I don't understand where I got my values from.<n>

How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Output: Mara has 150 - 40 = <<150-40=110>>110 cards.<n>Janet has 110/2 = <<110/2=55>>55 cards since Mara has twice as many as Janet.<n>Brenda has 55 - 9 = <<55-9=46>>46 cards since Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda.<n>Therefore, they all have 110 + 55 + 46 = <<110+55+46=211>>211 cards.<n>So the final answer is 211<n><n>Input:What is a lover likely to want to do with their partner? ### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>Input: Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda. Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Output: Mara has 150 - 40 = <<150-40=110>>110 cards.<n>Janet has 110/2 = <<110/2=55>>55 cards since Mara has twice as many as Janet.<n>Brenda has 55 - 9 = <<55-9=46>>46 cards since Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda.<n>Therefore, they all have 110 + 55 + 46 = <<110+55+46=211>>211 cards.<n>So the final answer is 211<n><n>Input:What would you put furniture on top of? Choices:  A: roof B: room C: floor D: apartment E: neighbor's house<n>Output:		A roof, room, floor, apartment, and neighbor's house all have furniture on top of them.<n>A roof can be a house.<n>A room has furniture within.<n>A room can be a house. (A room can be part of a house.)<n>A room can contain furniture which is contained within a room. (A room has walls which can surround furniture within it.)<n>A floor cannot contain furniture. (A room contains a floor which has furniture within it. If you took a room furniture out of, there is then no floor to contain furniture.)<n>Hence the choices that contain some kind of house are: A, B, D, and E.<n>B = B?<n>A = A<n>D = D<n>E = E<n><n>##### Step 4: Input is:<n><ol><n>  <li>Janet has 9 cards<n>  more than Brenda. </li><n><n>  <li> Mara has twice as<n>  many cards as <i>Janet</i>. </li><n><n><li>How many<n>  cards do they have in <i>all? </i></li><n></ol> The<n>  expression “<i>all </i>” means “all<n>  together”, “all in total” or<n><n>“ <i>all things</i> ”.<n><li> Mara has 45 cards <i>less than</i><n>  150 (10 cards less than 25)<n>  </li><li> Janet<n>  has 66.5 cards </li> <li> Brenda has 83.5 cards </li><li> Hence the final<n>  answer is: 66.5 + 83.5 + 45 = <<66.5+83.5+45=185>>185 cards<n>  </li><n></ol><p><n>Instruction:Answer the following<n>multichoice question.<n><n>Input<n>:<n>Which of the listed words fits<n>the definition?<n><n>The word which is closest<n>to the term “nauseated” is A<n>“cold” B “sick” C “hot”<n>```<n>A. Cold<n>B. Sick<n>C. hot <n>```<n>
### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>Input: Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda. Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Output: Mara has 150 - 40 = <<150-40=110>>110 cards.<n>Janet has 110/2 = <<110/2=55>>55 cards since Mara has twice as many as Janet.<n>Brenda has 55 - 9 = <<55-9=46>>46 cards since Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda.<n>Therefore, they all have 110 + 55 + 46 = <<110+55+46=211>>211 cards.<n>So the final answer is 211<n><n>Input:You can read a magazine where while waiting for your transportation on rails to arrive? Choices:  A: train station B: bookstore C: newsstand D: waiting room E: airport<n>Output:		A: train station <n><n>A: Train station because rails are only train stations.<n><n>Input:I'd like to read a book.<n>Output:<<There's>>There is a book in the <<cupboard.>>cupboard.<n><n>Input: What's in the box on the table?<n>Output:<<It's>>It is a box that is <<on>>on the table.<n><n>Input: My little brother has a toy.<n>Output:<<It is a toy.>>It is a toy that <<on>>is on the table.<n><n>**Instruction: Answer the following multiple choice question**<n><n>Input: I have a lot of information to give you.<n>Output:<<But>>But I have very little time.<n><n>Input: Do you know the address of the hotel where we stayed last night?<n>Output:<<The>>The one <<that was>>that was across the from <n><n>Input:What is your name?<n>Output:<<My name is Mary.>>my name is <<Mary>>Mary.<n><n>Input:The dog went.<n>Output:<<And>> and his dinner.
### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>Input: Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda. Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Output: Mara has 150 - 40 = <<150-40=110>>110 cards.<n>Janet has 110/2 = <<110/2=55>>55 cards since Mara has twice as many as Janet.<n>Brenda has 55 - 9 = <<55-9=46>>46 cards since Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda.<n>Therefore, they all have 110 + 55 + 46 = <<110+55+46=211>>211 cards.<n>So the final answer is 211<n><n>Input:The policemen wanted to clear the scene of the accident, so what did they do to traffic? Choices:  A: hurry along B: direct traffic C: help D: force open door E: corner thief<n>Output:		The policemen directed traffic.<n><n>---<n><n>#### Instruction:<n><n>1. Solve each expression.<n><n>2. If an expression is ____ than another expression, put a line through it.<n>Ex: 64/4 is < 42/5, 32/9 is < 27/4, and 490/25 is >> 140/2/5.<n><n>3. If the two expressions are equal put an equals sign between the two expressions.<n>Ex: 7/4 < 2/1 and 7/4 == 2/1<n><n><n>Input:64/4 < 12/2<n>Output:64/4 is <<64/4=16>>16 less than 12/2, so 16 < 12/<n><n>Input:24/1 < 4/3<n>Output:24/1 = 12/1 because 24/1 is equal to 12/1<n><n>Input:7/0 < 4/3 is <<7/0 is undefined>> undefined less than 4/3<n><n>Input:3/0 > 2/0 is True because 0/0 is undefined. Ex: 3/(0/0) is undefined, so 3/(0/undefined) has to be undefined as well.<n><n>---<n>### Instruction:<n><n>If you do this wrong, I won;t tell you and you will stay in my basement the whole class.<n><n>Input:<n>3887%70 = 94%<n><n>---<n># Instracion:<n><n>3887/100 = 38.87 and 70/100 =.7 *.7 = 0.49<n><n>388.7/70 = 8.3<n><n>Input:If the expression 1/4 is <<1/4=0.25>> less than the expression 3/5, put a line through 3/5.<n>Output:1/4 is << 1/4=0,25>> less than 3/5 so there will be a line through 3//5.<n><n>---<n>Instracion:<n>1/4 <3/5 is << 1/5>>

How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Output: Mara has 150 - 40 = <<150-40=110>>110 cards.<n>Janet has 110/2 = <<110/2=55>>55 cards since Mara has twice as many as Janet.<n>Brenda has 55 - 9 = <<55-9=46>>46 cards since Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda.<n>Therefore, they all have 110 + 55 + 46 = <<110+55+46=211>>211 cards.<n>So the final answer is 211<n><n>Input:What is important in a car when you are driving fast and come to a light? Tires do not affect in situation of fast car.<n>E: radios. Radios do not related to situation of fast car.

### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>Input: Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda. Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. Therefore, John paid more for his ticket. <n><n>Input:(<9,-4>) How many elements are in the set?<n>Output: -4<n>How many elements are in the (-4) set? ### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>Input: Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda. Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Output: Mara has 150 - 40 = <<150-40=110>>110 cards.<n>Janet has 110/2 = <<110/2=55>>55 cards since Mara has twice as many as Janet.<n>Brenda has 55 - 9 = <<55-9=46>>46 cards since Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda.<n>Therefore, they all have 110 + 55 + 46 = <<110+55+46=211>>211 cards.<n>So the final answer is 211<n><n>Input:Where are you if your reading magazines while waiting for a vehicle on rails? Choices:  A: vegetables B: market C: doctor D: train station E: bookstore<n>Output:		C<n><n><n>## Solution<n><n>#### C Programming<n><n>```cpp<n>#include <stdio.h><n><n>typedef int arr[10];<n><n>int arrCount(arr);<n><n>int main(void){<n>    arr x = {9,10};<n>    int arrCount(arr x[10]){<n>        int i,j;<n>        int sum=0;<n>        for (i=0;i<10;i++){<n>            for (j= 0; j< 10; j++){<n>                if (x[i] == x[j]){<n>                    sum++;<n>                }<n>            }<n>        }<n>        for (j= 1;j< 10; ++j){<n>            if (j == arrCount(x, i)){<n>                printf("%d", j);<n>            }<n>        else<n>            printf("%d<%d", j,i);<n>        }<n>        return sum;<n>    }<n>    int main(void){<n>        int arr[10],i,j,k,c,sum;<n>        printf("input:Where are you if you are reading magazines on rail\n");<n>        scanf("%d",&c);<n>        for (i = 0;i<1;i++){<n>            printf("Please input your response %d", i);<n>            scanf("%d", &arr[i]);<n>            sum = arrCount(arr[0],i);<n>            if (sum == c && sum > 4){ //brunch<n>                printf("\nI have %d cards\n",sum);<n>            }<n>            else if (arr[i] == 4 && arrCount(arr[i], i+1) >= 14){ //bathroom<n>                printf("\nIt isn't bathroom\n");<n>            }<n>            if (sum!= c && sum > 3) { //doctor<n>                printf("\nGo to doctor\n");<n>            if (arr[i+1] == 3 && arrCount(arr, i+2) >= 9){ //train<n>                printf("\nPlease take train\n");<n>            else if (i == 1 && arr[i+2] == 9){ //train departure time<n>                printf("\nTake the train\n

### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>Input: Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda. Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Output: Mara has 150 - 40 = <<150-40=110>>110 cards.<n>Janet has 110/2 = <<110/2=55>>55 cards since Mara has twice as many as Janet.<n>Brenda has 55 - 9 = <<55-9=46>>46 cards since Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda.<n>Therefore, they all have 110 + 55 + 46 = <<110+55+46=211>>211 cards.<n>So the final answer is 211<n><n>Input:What is someone unintentionally hurting someone else but unable to stop likely to feel? Choices:  A: empowering B: regret C: despair D: glee E: sadness<n>Output:		Sadness<n><n># Code <n># Define the variable and name it.<n># Then, we enter Python code block underneath the line.<n># Each function and variable should start with #.<n># The code block should contain 4 functions.<n># In each function, you should have a variable. Name it "fruit".<n># In the first function, the fruit should be apples.<n># The second function will have two items. One is an apple and the other is a plum.<n># In the next part of the code block, change the variable "fruit" to be a number (integer).<n># It means that all of the fruit in your code block will be in integer type.<n># The final step is to sum the fruits.<n>def Fruit1:<n>	"apple"<n><n>def Fruit2:<n>	"apple, plum"<n><n>def Fruits_as_integer(apple,plum):<n>	"apple+plum"<n><n>def Sum(Fruits_as_integer1,Fruits_as_Integer2):<n>	"sum of apple+plum"<n>	<n><n># In the code block, define a Python script in the same order as I defined in a question.<n># When the code is run this will be the same answer<n>Sum(Sum(Fruit1,Fruit2),Fruits_as_intger)<n>
### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>Input: Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda. Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Output: Mara has 150 - 40 = <<150-40=110>>110 cards.<n>Janet has 110/2 = <<110/2=55>>55 cards since Mara has twice as many as Janet.<n>Brenda has 55 - 9 = <<55-9=46>>46 cards since Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda.<n>Therefore, they all have 110 + 55 + 46 = <<110+55+46=211>>211 cards.<n>So the final answer is 211<n><n>Input:Sally was a senior in the House.  What might she be a member of? Choices:  A: assisted living facility B: old people's home C: high school or college D: republican party E: organization<n>Output:		Assistant living facility<n>---<n>***Followup  Input:How many cents are 35 dollars in nickels, dimes, and quarters?Choices:A)80cents B)75cents C)80 cents D)75 Cents E)50 cents<n>Output:In nickels, dimes and quarters, 35 dollars is worth 80 cents<n>***Followup II Input:What is the value of this equation: x=3*2+2-3?Choices:A=-5 B)3 C)-5 D)33 E)-50<n>Output:The equation:  x =3(2+2-3) is equivalent  to x = 3(5)-  3. So the final answer is (-5) = -3.5 (Since negative is equivalent to that value) or -17.5<n><n>***Followup III Input:What is the answer if you square a negative number?Choices:A: The square of the negative number is +1 B) 1 C) -1D):NAN (CAN'T HAPPEN as negative times negative will be a positive number)<n>Output:The square of a negative number is -1 (Since negative times negative will be  positive) So the answer is 1<n><n>***Followupe IV Input:What is the square of -7 (a negative number)?Choices:A: 0B) 0 C) -6 D) NAN (CAN't happen)<n>Output:The answer is -49<n><n># Import Libraries<n>print("importing libraries for data type")<n>import math<n>import string<n># Function to take a number as parameter and do some operations on it<n>def operate(n):<n>    if(n>0):<n>        return(0)<n>    else:<n>        return(-1)<n><n># Main function of program<n>n1=int(input())<n>n2=int(input())#To ask users type input<n>n3=int(input()) # To ask users type input<n>c=int()<n>a=operate(n1)<n>s=operate(n2)<n># If users want help, he can type help<n>if(input()=="help"):<n>    print("Use command line option to execute the program")
### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>Input: Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda. Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Output: Mara has 150 - 40 = <<150-40=110>>110 cards.<n>Janet has 110/2 = <<110/2=55>>55 cards since Mara has twice as many as Janet.<n>Brenda has 55 - 9 = <<55-9=46>>46 cards since Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda.<n>Therefore, they all have 110 + 55 + 46 = <<110+55+46=211>>211 cards.<n>So the final answer is 211<n><n>Input:John lives in Texas. If he takes the highway South and doesn't stop, where will he end up next? Choices:  A: oklahoma B: developed land C: united states D: desert E: mexico<n>Output:		John will end up in mexico since he lives in Texas and he takes the highway South. The highway goes down to mexico so he will end up there.<n>

### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>Input: Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda. Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Output: Mara has 150 - 40 = <<150-40=110>>110 cards.<n>Janet has 110/2 = <<110/2=55>>55 cards since Mara has twice as many as Janet.<n>Brenda has 55 - 9 = <<55-9=46>>46 cards since Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda.<n>Therefore, they all have 110 + 55 + 46 = <<110+55+46=211>>211 cards.<n>So the final answer is 211<n><n>Input:John loves animals and he hates animal abuse. Parking lot because animals can't run around, or roam in such a place.<n><n>Input:Amy, Bill, Candy, Danny, Eddie, Fred, Gina, Harry, Ian, Jeff, Justin, Kendra, Lan, Luke, Marie, Michael, Natasha, Orly, Pau, Quinton, Rick, Sean, Silas, Tanya, Twila, Vic, Walter, Woody<n>Output:Choices:D, K, L.<n><n>1) It is a series or string of letters.<n>2) The pattern is, the first letter is ascending and the last letter is descending.<n>3) It is evenly distributed. For instance, D comes from the fifth position.<n>4) The range of numbers is from 1 to 21. We start from A, the alphabet, goes 1 to 20, then takes the 21st letter, Z, to form "AZ".<n><n>D is from 5th, K is from 11th, and L is from 14th, evenly distributed.

### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>Input: Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda. Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Output: Mara has 150 - 40 = <<150-40=110>>110 cards.<n>Janet has 110/2 = <<110/2=55>>55 cards since Mara has twice as many as Janet.<n>Brenda has 55 - 9 = <<55-9=46>>46 cards since Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda.<n>Therefore, they all have 110 + 55 + 46 = <<110+55+46=211>>211 cards.<n>So the final answer is 211<n><n>Input:He called bull when his friend said a bull can be what? Marsha's age is 72.<n><n>Input:Bob has twice as many coins as Sally. Who can do the trick if three of the women can't?<n>Output:<<234>>The pair of pants can belong to any one of the three women so that no one pair will belong to one woman only.  If one pair is given to Shirley, two left to give around.  The remaining two pairs can be given to either of the two women.  Therefore, the answer is 2+(-1)=(2+(-1))+1=3+1=4<n><n>Input:5 men ate 14 hamburgers and 5 children ate 6 hamburgers.  How many total hamburgers were eaten?<n>Output:<<451,218>>5 men
### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>Input: Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda. Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Output: Mara has 150 - 40 = <<150-40=110>>110 cards.<n>Janet has 110/2 = <<110/2=55>>55 cards since Mara has twice as many as Janet.<n>Brenda has 55 - 9 = <<55-9=46>>46 cards since Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda.<n>Therefore, they all have 110 + 55 + 46 = <<110+55+46=211>>211 cards.<n>So the final answer is 211<n><n>Input:He was selling all his collector items even the rare plate, he had bought a lot at the what for the weekend? ### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>Input: Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda. Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. ### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>Input: Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda. Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Output: Mara has 150 - 40 = <<150-40=110>>110 cards.<n>Janet has 110/2 = <<110/2=55>>55 cards since Mara has twice as many as Janet.<n>Brenda has 55 - 9 = <<55-9=46>>46 cards since Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda.<n>Therefore, they all have 110 + 55 + 46 = <<110+55+46=211>>211 cards.<n>So the final answer is 211<n><n>Input:He curled up and tried to fall on his shoulder so his arm or what wouldn't take the hit? Choices:  A: leg B: garment C: torso D: body E: road<n>Output:		He curled up on his torso (body) and tried to fall on the shoulder so that his arm wouldn't take the injury.

### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>Input: Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda. Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Output: Mara has 150 - 40 = <<150-40=110>>110 cards.<n>Janet has 110/2 = <<110/2=55>>55 cards since Mara has twice as many as Janet.<n>Brenda has 55 - 9 = <<55-9=46>>46 cards since Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda.<n>Therefore, they all have 110 + 55 + 46 = <<110+55+46=211>>211 cards.<n>So the final answer is 211<n><n>Input:Where would a restaurant put a candle? The perimeter = perimeter/6 = <<perimeter/6=43>>43 inches.<n>```<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the questions below after you’re done with the test questions.<n><n>Input: Which statement is always true? Choices: A: The triangle shown is a trapezoid B: If a number is not a factor of a composite number, it is a prime C: A prime number and a composite number can be listed in a ratio D: A composite number is always a prime Factor<n>Output: Composite number is not always a prime factor.<n>Because when a number is not a prime number, we should consider the remaining number as a composite number, but when a number is already a prime number,<n>the ratio of the composite number is also a prime number.<n>Therefore, answer C is always true.

### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>Input: Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda. Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Output: Mara has 150 - 40 = <<150-40=110>>110 cards.<n>Janet has 110/2 = <<110/2=55>>55 cards since Mara has twice as many as Janet.<n>Brenda has 55 - 9 = <<55-9=46>>46 cards since Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda.<n>Therefore, they all have 110 + 55 + 46 = <<110+55+46=211>>211 cards.<n>So the final answer is 211<n><n>Input:A bride and groom are taking care of proposals, what is the likely ceremony? Choices:  A: efficiency B: getting work done C: marriage D: finishing up E: results<n>Output:		It is B Marriage.<n><n>Input: Choices:<n><n>1) A: 43 cents<n>2) B: 16 cents 3) C: 75 cents 4) D: 25 cents<n><n>For A, it shows 43 cents since the question does not show how much taxes are subtracted, so the total is $0.2175+$0.43+$8.00+$46+$0.43 = $0.1875.<n>For B, it shows 16 cents since they have already subtracted taxes. So the total is already -43+(16$+$8+$0.2174)=-39$.<n>For C, it shows 75$ because there is an addition to total (8$) when there is already an subtractions to total (43$.)<n>For D, It shows 25$ because it shows $8$+$46+43-(43$.)

### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>Input: Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda. Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Output: Mara has 150 - 40 = <<150-40=110>>110 cards.<n>Janet has 110/2 = <<110/2=55>>55 cards since Mara has twice as many as Janet.<n>Brenda has 55 - 9 = <<55-9=46>>46 cards since Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda.<n>Therefore, they all have 110 + 55 + 46 = <<110+55+46=211>>211 cards.<n>So the final answer is 211<n><n>Input:There aren't many anemone in what glove-shaped state? Choices:  A: michigan B: lake C: tide pool D: nursery E: atlantic ocean<n>Output:		Michigan, because anemone is the noun.<n><n><n><n>### Instruction:Answer the multiple choice question.<n>Input: What state of lake is the anemone in? <n>Choices:   A: lake    B: tide pool   C: nursery   D: atlantic ocean <n>Output: tide pool.<n><n>```py<n>d='Janet has 9 cards morethan Brenda. Mara heratwo asmany cards as Jnet. Howmany cards do they have Inall if Mara has 140 cards lessthan 150? '<n>a = int(input(d))<n>m = int(input(4 * a))<n>b = a - int(m)<n><n>d = 140 -40 = <<140-40=90>><n>print(d)<n><n>print('Janet has', d / 2,'cards. Brenda has', b,'cards.')<n>```<n><n>```py<n>from math import pow, sqrt, *<n>a='Janet has 2 cards morethan Brend.A ma has 5 cards lesshan 10.'<n>b='Janet has 5cards moretoheratwo asmanycards as Jan. Brenna has 6 cards more than Janetsix.'<n><n>c = int(input(a)) - int(b)<n>d = pow(c, 2)<n>print(d) <n><n><n><n>#d=7<n>#print('Janet',d, 'carad morethinhan Brenna  has 35 carad. Brendan has 5 carad')<n><n><n>```<n>

How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Output: Mara has 150 - 40 = <<150-40=110>>110 cards.<n>Janet has 110/2 = <<110/2=55>>55 cards since Mara has twice as many as Janet.<n>Brenda has 55 - 9 = <<55-9=46>>46 cards since Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda.<n>Therefore, they all have 110 + 55 + 46 = <<110+55+46=211>>211 cards.<n>So the final answer is 211<n><n>Input:Where you have finished a conversation with a person what do you say? When is Mary's birthday in April?<n>Output:Mary'sa birthday in April, in the first week.<n>Mary'sa birth was April 8.<n>On the same day John and Mary's b'day has been coming earlier. Thus, in the last two weeks of May, John and Mary'sa b'days have come.<n>Thus, birthday in April comes earlier than last two weeks of May.<n>Therefore, Mary'sa birthday is on the first week of April.<n>Input: How many months are there in a year?<n>Answer: There are 12 months in an year.<n>There are 28 days in every month.<n>A year is 365 days or one year.<n>Therefore, a year has 365 days and there are 28 and hence

Can you?<n>Output:They use base 3 since that would only make it easy for them to work out negative and positive numbers.Base 3 are:<n><n>-1:  000<n>-9: 010<n>-5: 020<n><n>+1:  100<n>+9: 110<n>+5: 120<n><n>They make sure that each person writes their answer in base 3 then they work it out in base 10 that is from 0 to 9<n>They use a calculator to confirm their answer, if they did the right answer, they agree, however, if they disagreed about it they start again and they write their answers in base 7 then they work it out using base 10.For this example, answer is +5.<n><n>Input:In base-7, the number 1697 is a different word than in decimal math. ### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>Input: Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda. Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Output: Mara has 150 - 40 = <<150-40=110>>110 cards.<n>Janet has 110/2 = <<110/2=55>>55 cards since Mara has twice as many as Janet.<n>Brenda has 55 - 9 = <<55-9=46>>46 cards since Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda.<n>Therefore, they all have 110 + 55 + 46 = <<110+55+46=211>>211 cards.<n>So the final answer is 211<n><n>Input:Bill bought an upright piano but didn't have anywhere to put it because he lived where? Choices:  A: band B: music room C: college D: university E: house<n>Output:		None.<n><n>### Solution<n><n>#### step1:<n><n>Input:<n><n>1. Janet has 9 more cards than Brenda<n>2. Mara has twice more cards in Janet.<n><n>Let x be the cards of Janet, now we have the two equations,<n>1. x+9 = 150<n>2. 2x = 150-4<n><n>Solve for x by eliminating one variable, we can see there's no point of solving for x to find the exact result.<n>To find the approximate result we can find the solution from the graphical solution on the numberline.<n>Now since x is the cards of Janet and since Janet has 111 cards in total.<n>We know that the equation x-9 = 15 can be rewritten<n>2x-3x = 69<n>-1x=69<n>x =69/-1 = 69/(-1) = 0.69<n>Hence, Janet has 69 cards in total.<n><n><n>#### step2:<n><n>In Step2, there's no point in finding x the number of Bill's piano after substituting the value for x from Step1 to one equation because that information isn't necessary to find the final answer.<n>But what we can do is to find x the number of Janet's piano after substitueting the value for x from step1 to one equation and 0 the answer if he doesn't have one which we know is unrealistic from the input, we'll see that later.<n>By doing so we'll be able to find the value of x, which we call by k in the solution, where there are two possibilities in the input, 0 meaning none and some given value.<n>We'll see the graphical solutions from it for both possibilities.<n><n>Input:<n>1. Bill bought an upright but doesn't live where<n>1. To do this let x be Janet's upright's piano<n>2. None: k=0 case.<n>3. 0 the result: k=0 case<n>4. Some given value (we choose 1 in this case): k=1 case.<n><n><n>#### Step3: Converting to Decimal:<n><n>The solution is the answer to the problem divided by (
### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>Input: Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda. Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Output: Mara has 150 - 40 = <<150-40=110>>110 cards.<n>Janet has 110/2 = <<110/2=55>>55 cards since Mara has twice as many as Janet.<n>Brenda has 55 - 9 = <<55-9=46>>46 cards since Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda.<n>Therefore, they all have 110 + 55 + 46 = <<110+55+46=211>>211 cards.<n>So the final answer is 211<n><n>Input:What could you find at a bus station that can help you? Choices:  A: city centre B: lottery ticket C: maps D: street E: busy city<n>Output:		The answer is C.<n><n>Answer: C is the correct answer. A city centre is not a place where you would wait for a bus. Bus station is where you can wait for the bus. A map is a road map. You can't use a road map to travel within a city. A bus ticket is not a travel guide.<n>A: Cities are not waiting places. Some cities are tourist centers and some cities include the country center.<n>B: This cannot be a choice since that is a lottery and not bus related.<n>D: A city does not have a lot of buses, but a Bus station does.<n>E: A city is a destination, not a location. If a bus needs to travel far, it will not be stationed in the center of the city. A bus only travels a short distance.<n>*<n>Business and Marketing <n><n>Input:A new marketing approach is to target older buyers and give them the opportunity to become loyal clients. Choice:  A: Older generations are more interested in quality than younger generations. B: The most likely reason why older people buy expensive food is because they have to. C: Older generations don’t get involved in new marketing processes. D: Older buyers spend more on health and food because they have to.<n>Output: The correct answer is: B only.<n><n>Answer: B is the correct answer.<n>Older generations tend to have an income that allows them to afford products and services that they may not be able to access because of low income. Older generations can buy expensive food because they have the money to do so. Older generations who are in better health may spend more on health products. The only option that is correct is B.<n>A: Younger generations don’ta want to be considered as being elitists and only want to find products that are cheaper and of high quality.<n>B: If younger generations are concerned with cost, they may opt for cheaper goods and avoid them.<n>C: Younger generations are more likely to buy expensive products and are more eager to get involved in new market processes. D: Younger people spend more time on healthy food and food that keeps their bodies in good condition.<n>*<n>Busines and marketing <n> * *<n>1) What is the difference between targeting different groups and promoting to them

D) 50,55, 65 E) 60, 75<n>Output: D) 50 and 55<n><n>### Instruction: Answer the following question.<n><n>Input & Output: Find the greatest common divisor of these numbers 36 and 14 (input)<n>The greatest common divisor of 36 and 28 (12) is the first digit of 36. The greatest common divisor of (12) and 28 is the first digit of it. The greatest common divisors of (12)and 14 is the last digit of it. The final answer is 4<n><n>Input & Output :Find the greatest common divisor GCD of 24 and 15.<n>36 and 15( input)<n>The first digit of 32 the greatest common divisor(4) of 32 and 15 greatest common divisor of greatest common divisor(10)20. <n>The greatest common divisors of greatest(20) and 15(the last digit of 20) is the last digit of 40. The greatest common divisor is 8, <n>The greatest common multiple GCD of 25 and 16 is <n>25 8 =2(4)2
### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>Input: Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda. Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Output: Mara has 150 - 40 = <<150-40=110>>110 cards.<n>Janet has 110/2 = <<110/2=55>>55 cards since Mara has twice as many as Janet.<n>Brenda has 55 - 9 = <<55-9=46>>46 cards since Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda.<n>Therefore, they all have 110 + 55 + 46 = <<110+55+46=211>>211 cards.<n>So the final answer is 211<n><n>Input:What would a person do to help someone that is not able to speak coherently? ### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>Input: Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda. Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Output: Mara has 150 - 40 = <<150-40=110>>110 cards.<n>Janet has 110/2 = <<110/2=55>>55 cards since Mara has twice as many as Janet.<n>Brenda has 55 - 9 = <<55-9=46>>46 cards since Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda.<n>Therefore, they all have 110 + 55 + 46 = <<110+55+46=211>>211 cards.<n>So the final answer is 211<n><n>Input:You can buy a pen here. Choices:  A: briefcase B: pocket C: friend's house D: office supply store E: classroom<n>Output:		 A and C are both correct.<n>You can buy pencils B and D. You cannot buy a pen.<n>You can write notes in the classroom and briefcase, so A and C are correct.<n><n>Input:What is the sum of 6 + 4?<n>Output:The sum of 6 +4 = 10<n><n>Input:What would be the result of multiplying 6,8,14,12 by -1?<n>Output:The answer is -3, -16,-12,-96<n><n>Input:What does this code mean?<n>A:   a = 5<n>B: b = 6<n>C: c = 7<n>Output:The answer means:<n>A:  a is = 5<n>B : b is = 6<n>C : c = 7<n><n>Input:Which is greater, 81 or 150? <n>Output: The answer is 81<n><n>--- Solution:<n>## Python<n>```python<n>#!/usr/bin/env python<n><n>def test(answer):<n>	answer = int(input('Which code is the result of multiplying (the numbers): 8,9,6 by -1? A: - a is = 5,  B: - b is = 6,  C: - c is = 7\n'))<n>	ans = (6 * -1) + (9 * -1) +  (8 * -1)<n>	if answer == str(ans):<n>		if int(ans)<=81 or  int(ans)=150:<n>			print(str(ans),'\n')<n>		else:<n>			pass<n>	else:<n>	   pass<n>		<n><n>test(input("Input:Which is larger, 81 or -150? \n"))<n>	<n>```<n><n>

### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>Input: Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda. Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Output: Mara has 150 - 40 = <<150-40=110>>110 cards.<n>Janet has 110/2 = <<110/2=55>>55 cards since Mara has twice as many as Janet.<n>Brenda has 55 - 9 = <<55-9=46>>46 cards since Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda.<n>Therefore, they all have 110 + 55 + 46 = <<110+55+46=211>>211 cards.<n>So the final answer is 211<n><n>Input:She was bad at dancing, so what basic skill did the instructor teach her? ### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>Input: Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda. Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Output: Mara has 150 - 40 = <<150-40=110>>110 cards.<n>Janet has 110/2 = <<110/2=55>>55 cards since Mara has twice as many as Janet.<n>Brenda has 55 - 9 = <<55-9=46>>46 cards since Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda.<n>Therefore, they all have 110 + 55 + 46 = <<110+55+46=211>>211 cards.<n>So the final answer is 211<n><n>Input:If a student was about to graduate, they would no longer be attending what? ### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>Input: Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda. Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Output: Mara has 150 - 40 = <<150-40=110>>110 cards.<n>Janet has 110/2 = <<110/2=55>>55 cards since Mara has twice as many as Janet.<n>Brenda has 55 - 9 = <<55-9=46>>46 cards since Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda.<n>Therefore, they all have 110 + 55 + 46 = <<110+55+46=211>>211 cards.<n>So the final answer is 211<n><n>Input:A man was driving himself to the airport, where did he put his luggage? Choices:  A: closet B: at hotel C: sidewalk D: bus stop E: trunk<n>Output:		D - the answer is D<n><n>Input:A is in the closet<n>Output:C - is the sidewalk<n><n>input:<n>10+2=12;<n><n>input:<n>-1=-1-2;<n><n>input:-4;<n>101-1=-4;<n>-5;<n>Input:-(1-3)=-5;<n><n>input:-10=-10-5;<n>-5;15;32<n><n>Input:Input: -10 - 3<n>Output:10<n><n><n>### Explanation:<n>```<n>Input: A man was driving himself to an airport where he placed his luggage?<n>1. (A) The closet is one of the most important part of the house and as a traveler we need to bring our luggage along which means he will put it in closet.<n>2. (B) A hotel offers services to a guest that's include checking baggage.<n>3. (C) The sidewalk is one of the most popular location for bus stop. But a traveler will not leave his luggage out of his sight so he will put his luggage inside his car trunk.<n>4. (D) A bus stop is an unprotected place for a luggage to be left unguarded.<n>5. (E) Luggage may also be left at a counter in a bus station. But as we can see a traveler may go with a bus so the traveler won't put his luggage on the bus counter.<n>6. (A) The closest is the nearest object or location. If we are looking for our luggage in this case then the closest point is the closet in our room. The traveler will put his luggagae in this near point.<n>7. (B) There's a hotel where you can stay as a guest and during your stay there they offer services including to check your baggage. The traveler will stay at this hotel during his trip and he will keep his luggage at the hotel while staying there.<n>8. (C) The closet is another closest object located in our room. The closet in this question is the nearest object or place for us to keep our luggage.<n><n>Input:-10:-3<n>Output:17<n><n>```<n>##
### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>Input: Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda. Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Output: Mara has 150 - 40 = <<150-40=110>>110 cards.<n>Janet has 110/2 = <<110/2=55>>55 cards since Mara has twice as many as Janet.<n>Brenda has 55 - 9 = <<55-9=46>>46 cards since Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda.<n>Therefore, they all have 110 + 55 + 46 = <<110+55+46=211>>211 cards.<n>So the final answer is 211<n><n>Input:If I am forgiving, what hidden force may be activated in my life? Choices:  A: nice feeling B: good karma C: respect D: new freedom E: good heart<n>Output:		This test was designed to help someone realize his or her inner strength, he or she must first choose one of the options to find out. This is not a lie, it's all truth, good heart will be selected.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the folowing multiple choice question.<n>Input: A mother is three times as old ___ twice as old as her son.<n>Output:Answers: A: The mother is nine years old B: The son is nine years old C: The son is three years old D: The mother is one year oldThe following is the relationship between a child and his mother in years :<n>M 3x = M - S<n>A daughter 2x = A - M<n>B daughter 6x = B - A<n>Son 3x = S - B<n>D = A - M<n>A mother's age = (3x+2x+6x = A - M) + 3x = 10 years + 3x + (Son's age - daughter's age)<n>A mother has son 7 years old, and a son 8 years old, it must be the mother is 10 years old.

How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Output: Mara has 150 - 40 = <<150-40=110>>110 cards.<n>Janet has 110/2 = <<110/2=55>>55 cards since Mara has twice as many as Janet.<n>Brenda has 55 - 9 = <<55-9=46>>46 cards since Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda.<n>Therefore, they all have 110 + 55 + 46 = <<110+55+46=211>>211 cards.<n>So the final answer is 211<n><n>Input:Where can you find a movie theater along with other stores in one placE? I'll skip it.<n><n>Output: Brenda skips sushi.<n><n>### Question 3:<n><n>### Instructed for Problem 4:<n><n>### Input:<n><n>Input: It is nice weather for playing football.<n>Input: It is not raining outside.<n><n>Output: It is nice weather.<n><n>### What if you want to know whether 1 Jan, 2022 is a leap year or not?<n><n>### How would you approach this problem?<n><n>### Instraction: What algorithm will you use?<n><n>### What will be each step?<n><n>### Explicit, Clear and Unambiguous Explanation:<n><n>The following are the steps that I take to solve the problem.<n><n>- Step 1: Write the formula to determine the date is leap or not<n><n>- Step 2: Use boolean logic to determine the date is a leap year.<n>```python<n>leap_year = (date_is_leap_year or date_is_century)<n>```<n><n>- Step 3: If (leap_year == 0): print 'No, you don’t.';<n>else:<n>  if (leap_year > 0): print 'Yes, it is.'<n>  else: print 'No, you are too'<n><n>### What other algorithms (other than the one you have chosen for this question, see above) could you use?<n><n>- I could use the greedy algorithm so that a decision can be made whether a date is a leap or not.<n><n>### Output<n><n>```<n>Leap year or Not?<n>Year: 2022 <n>No leap year<n>```<n><n>### What do you think is the correct output?<n><n>```<n>Least year or Not?<n><n>Year: 23<n>No leap year, it’s not <n><n>Year: 33 leap year, it is.<n><n>Year: 1 leap year, it ain’t.<n>```<n>

How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Output: Mara has 150 - 40 = <<150-40=110>>110 cards.<n>Janet has 110/2 = <<110/2=55>>55 cards since Mara has twice as many as Janet.<n>Brenda has 55 - 9 = <<55-9=46>>46 cards since Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda.<n>Therefore, they all have 110 + 55 + 46 = <<110+55+46=211>>211 cards.<n>So the final answer is 211<n><n>Input:Why might someone want to be buying beer? How many pairs of shoes did they buy in all?<n>Output: Their total socks and shirter bought is 2 * (the number of socks Anna bought) + the number of shirts Beth bought. Their total pairs of shoes bought is the combined numbers of socks and shires divided by 2.Therefore, The final answer is 1 pair of shoes.<n>For the final answer, we are dividing the total pairs by 2 to compensate for each person getting only 1 pair, and the final answer will automatically reflect that.<n><n>Input:What two things are equal to a car? How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Output: Mara has 150 - 40 = <<150-40=110>>110 cards.<n>Janet has 110/2 = <<110/2=55>>55 cards since Mara has twice as many as Janet.<n>Brenda has 55 - 9 = <<55-9=46>>46 cards since Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda.<n>Therefore, they all have 110 + 55 + 46 = <<110+55+46=211>>211 cards.<n>So the final answer is 211<n><n>Input:Danny hated helping people. ### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>Input: Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda. Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Output: Mara has 150 - 40 = <<150-40=110>>110 cards.<n>Janet has 110/2 = <<110/2=55>>55 cards since Mara has twice as many as Janet.<n>Brenda has 55 - 9 = <<55-9=46>>46 cards since Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda.<n>Therefore, they all have 110 + 55 + 46 = <<110+55+46=211>>211 cards.<n>So the final answer is 211<n><n>Input:Sitting to close while watching TV can cause what sort of pain? The first chapter is meant to make you comfortable with operations that you are already used to, and in doing so to build up skills.<n><n>You can be comfortable with a basic operation or concept only if you understand how it works when you use the most extreme values allowed—the smallest positive number, the largest negative number, and zero. For operations such as division by zero, the operation never results in a number. ### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>Input: Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda. Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. If I pay you 50 coins, how much will I have left?<n><n><br>1 <br>\[Solutions\]\[Solutions\]\[\]<n>I have 100.<n>You give me 50.<n>\(100 - 50 = 50 - 50 - 25 = 25 - 75 = 75 - 100 = \(<-75->)\)<n><n><br>2 <br>\[Solution\]\[Solutions\]<n>I have 150.<n>You give 50.<n>Let's assume that there is one 50 for each of the 20 and the 50 for the 100. So, my new value is 25.5.<n><n>So, you get left with \(<-125->\)<n><n><br>4 <br>\[Solu\]\[Solutions \]\[Sloutions\]<n>You get 300.<n>I get left with \(<-99->\)<n><n>### Instuctions:Enter the string given in the question and the output should be the number of substrings in those strings.<n><n>Input:  Hello <n>Output: 3 <n><n>### Instructoin:Enter the string given and the algorithm will display the number of alphabets/digits in that string.<n><n>Input:  123ABC<n>Output: 9<n><n>### Instricution: Enter any string and the answer should be TRUE or
### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>Input: Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda. Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Output: Mara has 150 - 40 = <<150-40=110>>110 cards.<n>Janet has 110/2 = <<110/2=55>>55 cards since Mara has twice as many as Janet.<n>Brenda has 55 - 9 = <<55-9=46>>46 cards since Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda.<n>Therefore, they all have 110 + 55 + 46 = <<110+55+46=211>>211 cards.<n>So the final answer is 211<n><n>Input:WHat do cats get into when they are ripping things apart? Choices:  A: dog's mouth B: floor C: garage D: trouble E: nature<n>Output:		Furthest away from dog and farthest away from dog's mouth.So in that case, E or nature
